There is no biological basis for this idea.

The Consumer Rights Act 2015 will make it far easier for groups of consumers to seek compensation from firms that have fixed prices and formed cartels. It introduces "market power" as a ground for legal action, a legal right that will force companies to answer to their consumers.

Under the act, if consumer groups can demonstrate that an individual firm has a "significant market power" over a group of consumers, the group can take the firms to court in order to enforce a remedy such as compensation. The individual firms involved are barred from taking legal action themselves.

The law applies equally to the retail sector as it does the more general sector (including the construction and energy industry).

The law is set to force large companies in the retail sector, such as Woolworths and Coles, to reduce their prices.

But it will also have a massive impact on business in general.
